bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials documenting the history of the Library Company of Philadelphia. Items include: a typescript copy of Dorothy F. Grimm's doctoral dissertation "A History of the Library Company of Philadelphia, 1731-1835" (University of Pennsylvania, 1955); several printed histories (1835-1995) by various authors, including George M. Abbot, Austin K. Gray, and Edwin Wolf and a 1867 manuscript history by John Meredith Read; scrapbook (1936-1971) of newspaper clippings, photographs, magazine articles, correspondence, exhibition signs and announcements; scrapbook (1920s) containing correspondence, photographs of Library Company buildings, paintings and furniture; two scrapbooks of newspaper clippings (1850s-1930 and 1933-1939), which include certificates from other institutions, event announcements, and maps.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
